verses.text: After this, the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them two by two ahead of him into every town and place where he himself was about to go.
verses.comment: The number seventy-two mirrors the seventy elders chosen by Moses, symbolizing leadership and the universal mission. Some manuscripts read seventy instead of seventy-two; both numbers carry Old Testament significance (see Genesis 10:2-31).

verses.text: He said to them, 'The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Therefore, pray to the Lord of the harvest to send out workers into his harvest.'
verses.comment: Jesus expresses the need for more ministers in God's work; prayer precedes action in advancing God's kingdom.

verses.text: Go on your way; look, I am sending you out like lambs among wolves.
verses.comment: Jesus forewarns his followers of persecution, echoing sacrificial imagery that points towards Christian suffering and witness.

verses.text: Carry no money bag, no sack, no sandals, and greet no one on the road.
verses.comment: Jesus instructs reliance on God's provision and urgency for the mission, underscoring detachment from worldly concerns.

verses.text: Whatever house you enter, first say, 'Peace to this house!'
verses.comment: Giving peace was a traditional greeting; in this mission, it bestows a spiritual blessing real and effective, not mere words.

verses.text: If a person of peace is there, your peace will rest upon him; if not, it will return to you.
verses.comment: Peace is not just a greeting but a real blessing; the spiritual effects of God's ambassadors are decisive.

verses.text: Stay in that same house, eating and drinking what they provide, for the worker deserves his wages. Do not move from house to house.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the right of ministers to receive material support, laying groundwork for later Church practice (cf. 1 Tim. 5:17-18).

verses.text: Whenever you enter a town and they welcome you, eat what is set before you.
verses.comment: Acceptance of hospitality, even if it does not fit Jewish dietary regulations, foreshadows the mission to the Gentiles.

verses.text: Heal the sick there and say to them, 'The kingdom of God has drawn near to you.'
verses.comment: Healing is a sign of the kingdom's presence, confirming that Jesus’ mission is both spiritual and physical, tying grace to tangible actions.

verses.text: But whenever you enter a town and they do not welcome you, go into its streets and say,
verses.comment: This public act announces judgment, recalling prophets who warned unbelieving cities.

verses.text: 'Even the dust of your town that clings to our feet, we wipe off against you. Yet know this: the kingdom of God has come near.'
verses.comment: Shaking dust is a prophetic symbol (cf. Neh. 5:13); the kingdom comes even if rejected—a sober warning.

verses.text: I tell you, it will be more bearable on that day for Sodom than for that town.
verses.comment: 'That day' refers to judgment (see Amos 5:18). Rejecting Christ brings greater accountability.

verses.text: Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.
verses.comment: Repentance involves not just internal change but also outward expression (sackcloth, ashes). Even pagan cities would have responded.

verses.text: But it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you.
verses.comment: Judgment is greater for those with more revelation; accountability corresponds to privilege.

verses.text: And you, Capernaum, will you be exalted to heaven? You will be brought down to Hades.
verses.comment: Parallel to the fall of the proud in Isaiah. Capernaum, privileged by Christ’s presence, is judged severely for spiritual pride.

verses.text: Whoever hears you hears me, and whoever rejects you rejects me, and whoever rejects me rejects the One who sent me.
verses.comment: A high statement of authority. Jesus delegates his own mission and authority through his apostles—laying a foundation for the Church’s authority.

verses.text: The seventy-two returned with joy, saying, 'Lord, even the demons are subject to us in your name!'
verses.comment: Power over demons confirms the reality of Christ’s mission shared with his followers.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven.'
verses.comment: Jesus proclaims victory over evil, referencing both a literal event and the ongoing defeat of Satan. There are echoes of divine authority.

verses.text: Look, I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you.
verses.comment: The language recalls Psalm 91, signifying spiritual victory—affirming the special protection given to Christ’s ministers.

verses.text: Nevertheless, do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject to you; but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.'
verses.comment: The greatest blessing is being enrolled in eternal life—a reference to the heavenly book (cf. Dan. 12:1).

verses.text: At that time, Jesus rejoiced in the Holy Spirit and said, 'I praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and learned and revealed them to little children. Yes, Father, for this was your gracious will.'
verses.comment: A profound insight into the relationship between Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. Jesus’ prayer here is also a Trinitarian revelation.

verses.text: All things have been handed over to me by my Father, and no one knows who the Son is except the Father, and who the Father is except the Son and anyone to whom the Son chooses to reveal him.'
verses.comment: A remarkable claim to divinity and equality with the Father. Jesus’ self-awareness is explicit; he alone reveals the Father. See John 14:6-9.

verses.text: Turning to his disciples, he said privately, 'Blessed are the eyes that see what you see!'
verses.comment: Seeing Christ is the ultimate blessing; the disciples experience the fulfillment of ancient prophecies.

verses.text: For I tell you that many prophets and kings desired to see what you see, and did not see it, and to hear what you hear, and did not hear it.'
verses.comment: This echoes the longing of Israel for the Messiah. Fulfillment is in Christ.

verses.text: And behold, a lawyer stood up to test him, saying, 'Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?'
verses.comment: The question about inheriting eternal life addresses the heart of salvation; Jesus often turns such questions into deeper teaching.

verses.text: He said to him, 'What is written in the Law? How do you read it?'
verses.comment: Jesus leads the lawyer to reflect on Scripture itself, affirming the authority of the Law.

verses.text: He answered, 'You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength and with all your mind; and your neighbor as yourself.'
verses.comment: The lawyer summarizes the Law’s core: total love for God and neighbor. True religion balances faith and works.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'You have answered correctly; do this, and you will live.'
verses.comment: Obedience from the heart—not mere knowledge—brings life. Jesus confirms the unity of faith and works.

verses.text: But he, desiring to justify himself, said to Jesus, 'And who is my neighbor?'
verses.comment: The lawyer seeks to limit the call to love, a temptation to self-righteousness rather than genuine mercy.

verses.text: Jesus replied, 'A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and he fell among robbers, who stripped him, beat him, and departed, leaving him half dead.'
verses.comment: Jesus uses a parable to challenge social and religious barriers, illustrating the Law fulfilled through mercy.

verses.text: Now by chance a priest was going down that road, and when he saw him he passed by on the other side.
verses.comment: Priests, religiously influential, can fail in charity—righteousness is not only ritual but love.

verses.text: So likewise a Levite, when he came to the place and saw him, passed by on the other side.
verses.comment: Even Levites, tasked with service, can neglect mercy. The parable critiques mere outward religion.

verses.text: But a Samaritan, as he journeyed, came to where he was, and when he saw him, he was moved with compassion.
verses.comment: Samaritans, despised by Jews, exemplify true neighborly love. Jesus overturns ethnic and social prejudice by this choice.

verses.text: He went to him, bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he set him on his own animal and brought him to an inn and took care of him.
verses.comment: Oil and wine, symbols of healing and blessing, are practical elements. The Church’s care for the wounded is sacramental: visible acts with spiritual significance.

verses.text: The next day he took out two denarii, gave them to the innkeeper, and said, 'Take care of him, and whatever more you spend, I will repay you when I return.'
verses.comment: The Samaritan’s promise to return echoes Christ’s own return and his ongoing care for his people.

verses.text: 'Which of these three, do you think, proved to be a neighbor to the man who fell among the robbers?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ question emphasizes action—living out mercy—above identity or status.

verses.text: He said, 'The one who showed him mercy.' And Jesus said to him, 'Go and do likewise.'
verses.comment: Mercy is the heart of the Law. Real worship is imitating divine compassion.

verses.text: Now as they were traveling along, he entered a village. A woman named Martha welcomed him into her house.
verses.comment: Hospitality to Jesus is significant; Martha’s home becomes a place of meeting with the Lord.

verses.text: She had a sister called Mary, who sat at the Lord's feet and listened to his teaching.
verses.comment: Sitting at the feet was a disciple’s posture. Mary chooses contemplation, prioritizing listening to Christ over action.

verses.text: But Martha was distracted with much serving. She came up and said, 'Lord, do you not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her then to help me.'
verses.comment: Martha’s service is good, but she lets anxiety and comparison distract her.

verses.text: But the Lord answered her, 'Martha, Martha, you are anxious and troubled about many things,
verses.comment: Jesus gently corrects Martha. Interior peace and presence is a higher good than anxiety about service.

verses.text: but only one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen the good portion, which will not be taken away from her.'
verses.comment: The contemplative life—prayerful communion with Jesus—is the 'better part.' The passage points to the value of devotion at the heart of spiritual life, nourishing all action.
